articles.title: About
articles.contents:
Data graphics
I started doing data visualization work with an engineering education research group around 2008 and haven’t stopped. The iterative process we developed to “find the story” in our data has been instrumental in shaping my approach to data graphics. You can read more about our research at https://midfield.online/.

I occasionally write about visual rhetoric, graph design, and R on my Data Stories blog. Our day 3 case study is built on one of those essays.
Music
My dad was a guitar player and taught me my first chords. I’ve been songwriting and performing since my teens. I posted some draft tracks to SoundCloud.

A favorite musical pilgrimage is the annual Swannanoa Gathering near Asheville, NC in late July.
Work life
I am a graduate of California State University, Northridge (1991), and the University of Washington (1993, 1995), all in mechanical engineering. I taught at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology from 2000-2020. My favorite courses were design, system dynamics, measurement systems, and data visualization. I retired from teaching in 2020.

articles.title: Session 1
articles.description:
Limitations of common graph types. Demonstrating how to avoid   
limitations and improve perception, reasoning, and credibility.
articles.contents:
Limitations of common graph types
In the first session we demonstrate the perceptual limitations of common graph types and suggest more effective alternatives.

The rationale behind alternative designs is illustrated with the goals of
Improving perception of stories in the data
Making it easier to reason quantitatively about the data
Enhancing our credibility with the audience
[slides]

articles.title: Session 2
articles.description:
Expanding your graphical repertoire. Illustrating a repertoire of 
graph types and how they are suited to specific data structures.
articles.contents:
Expanding your graphical repertoire
In the second session we illustrate a repertoire of graph types and how they are suited to specific data structures and answering specific types of questions.

The session should encourage you to:
Understand the structure of your data
Understand the type of question the data can answer
Explore different graph types suited to the data and the question
Keep reading and learning—an unfamiliar design may be just what you need
[slides]

articles.title: Session 3
articles.description:
Critical thinking about visual information—a case study. 
Detecting and correcting deliberate visual lies that attempt 
to restrict reproductive rights.
articles.contents:
Critical thinking about visual information—a case study
In the third session we study the visual rhetoric of a deliberate visual lie in the pursuit of restricting reproductive rights. We focus on
How the authors abuse the conventions of visual rhetoric to serve their rhetorical goals
What legitimate stories these data tell
What legitimate questions the data raise
